Description: According to Jung, these are the male and female archetypes residing in the unconscious of individuals, respectively. The anima exemplifies the feminine principle in men, while the animus signifies the masculine principle in women.
Translation: And that it is He who created the two mates, the male and the female,
Relation: This verse from the Quran acknowledges the inherent duality and complementarity between males and females, emphasizing the creation of pairs - the male and the female. In the psychological concept of anima and animus by Carl Jung, these archetypes represent the feminine and masculine aspects within individuals, respectively. The verse speaks to the interconnectedness and balance between opposites, highlighting the idea that both male and female principles are essential components that when integrated, contribute to wholeness and harmony within an individual. Just as Allah created male and female pairs as complements in nature, Jungs concept of anima and animus emphasizes the integration of both feminine and masculine characteristics within the psyche for personal growth and individuation.

Description: In Jungian psychology, these represent universal, primal, and collective mental representations inherited from our earliest ancestors. They are prevalent in literature, art, and religious iconography across cultures and serve to channel experiences and emotions, resulting in recognizable behavior patterns.
Translation: And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], Am I not your Lord? They said, Yes, we have testified. [This] - lest you should say on the Day of Resurrection, Indeed, we were of this unaware.
Relation: This verse highlights the belief in the concept of archetypes in Jungian psychology by indicating a collective primordial memory or recognition of a higher power within humanity. The idea that all human beings were once gathered together and made to bear witness to the existence and lordship of God taps into the notion of inherited, universal mental representations that transcend individual experiences. In the context of archetypes, this verse can be seen as portraying a deep, innate connection that all humans share with the divine or spiritual realm, serving as a fundamental archetype within the collective unconscious.

Description: A term coined by Carl Jung, it posits the existence of a shared part of the unconscious mind among all humans, deriving from ancestral memory. It’s believed to contain archetypes, universal images, patterns, and instincts inherent in all of us.
Translation: And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], Am I not your Lord? They said, Yes, we have testified. [This] - lest you should say on the Day of Resurrection, Indeed, we were of this unaware.
Relation: This verse highlights the idea of a shared experience or memory that all humans carry within them. The concept of all humans being created from a single soul and bearing witness to their acknowledgment of God before birth can be seen as a representation of a collective unconscious. It suggests a deep, universal connection among all individuals that transcends individual consciousness, resembling the notion of a shared unconscious part of the mind as proposed by Carl Jung.

Description: This refers to a therapist’s emotions and responses to a client, which can stem from the therapist’s own personal history. It’s typically considered as hindrance to therapy but can provide insight into the dynamics of the therapeutic relationship.
Translation: And We will remove whatever of ill-feeling is in their breasts. Rivers flow beneath them. And they will say: Praise be to Allah, Who has guided us to this. We would not have found the way had Allah not guided us. Certainly the messengers of our Lord brought the Truth. And it will be cried out to them: This is the Garden you have inherited in return for what you used to do. (7:43)
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Araf highlights the concept of divine guidance and healing of emotional wounds. In the context of Countertransference, therapists may experience a range of emotions towards their clients, stemming from their own personal history and unresolved issues. However, just as Allah promises to remove ill-feelings from the hearts of believers and guide them towards healing and gratitude, therapists can also seek self-awareness, introspection, and guidance to overcome their countertransference reactions. By acknowledging and addressing these emotions, therapists can gain deeper insight into the dynamics of the therapeutic relationship and ultimately provide more effective support to their clients.

Description: This is a compelling concept from Freud that suggests humans possess an inherent drive towards death and self-destruction. It counterbalances Eros (the life drive) and is often associated with aggressive behaviors.
Translation: Every soul will taste death, and you will only be given your full compensation on the Day of Resurrection. So he who is drawn away from the Fire and admitted to Paradise has attained [his desire]. And what is the life of this world except the enjoyment of delusion.
Relation: This verse from the Quran reminds believers of the inevitable reality of death that every soul will face. The concept of the death drive in psychoanalytic psychology aligns with the acknowledgment that all individuals, regardless of their desires and pursuits, will ultimately experience death. The idea of a human drive towards death and self-destruction can be viewed through the lens of this verse, emphasizing the transient nature of worldly pursuits and the importance of preparing for the afterlife. The verse serves as a reflective reminder that the ultimate goal should be to strive for salvation and eternal life in Paradise rather than being consumed by the fleeting pleasures of this world.

Description: These are strategies employed by the ego to mediate the conflict between the id and superego. They are unconscious mental processes that guard the individual from anxiety or unacceptable thoughts and feelings.
Translation: And if an evil suggestion comes to you from Satan, then seek refuge in Allah. Indeed, He is Hearing and Knowing.
Relation: This verse can be related to the concept of defense mechanisms in psychoanalytic psychology. In times of distress or when faced with unacceptable thoughts and feelings, seeking refuge in Allah can be considered a form of defense mechanism to protect oneself from negative influences or temptations. Just as how seeking refuge in Allah provides a shield from evil suggestions, defense mechanisms in psychology aim to protect the individuals psyche from anxiety or disturbing thoughts by employing various strategies.

Description: This defense mechanism in psychoanalysis involves shifting of impulses from an unacceptable target to a safer or more acceptable one. An example is redirecting aggression from a boss to a less-threatening loved one.
Translation: Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly fabricated a tremendous sin.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of displacement by emphasizing the idea of redirecting ones focus and actions from associating others with Allah, which is considered a grave sin, to seeking forgiveness and repentance from Allah. In the context of psychological displacement, this can be compared to the redirection of impulses or emotions from a harmful or unacceptable target (association with others besides Allah) to a safer or more acceptable one (sincere repentance and seeking forgiveness from Allah). Just as displacement in psychoanalytic psychology involves shifting emotions to a less-threatening target, seeking forgiveness from Allah offers a healthier outlet for dealing with guilt or wrongdoings.

Description: This is a key technique in psychoanalysis that interprets dreams to unearth unconscious desires or concerns. Freud viewed dreams as ‘the royal road to the subconscious,’ conveying unspeakable desires.
Translation: And they swear by Allah their strongest oaths that Allah will not raise up him who dies. Yes, it is a promise binding upon Him in truth, but most of mankind do not know.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Anam can be related to the concept of dream analysis in psychoanalytic psychology. In dream analysis, individuals often uncover unconscious desires, fears, and concerns that are not readily apparent in waking life. Similarly, the idea of Allah raising the dead in the afterlife can symbolize the revival of hidden thoughts and feelings that are buried in the subconscious mind. Just as dreams can reveal deeper truths about a persons psyche, the concept of resurrection in the Quran highlights the uncovering of hidden truths and the ultimate accountability of the soul. The verse emphasizes that despite peoples ignorance of this reality, it is a truth that remains binding and significant. This connection underscores the importance of introspection, self-awareness, and understanding the deeper layers of ones psyche for personal growth and development.

Description: This concept, proposed by Carl Jung, is the female counterpart of the Oedipus complex. It entails a girl’s psychosexual competition with her mother for her father’s attraction.
Translation: And when she heard of their scheming, she sent for them and prepared for them a banquet and gave each one of them a knife and said to Joseph, Come out before them. And when they saw him, they greatly admired him and cut their hands and said, Perfect is Allah! This is not a man; this is none but a noble angel.
Relation: This verse from the Quran relates to the concept of Electra complex in the sense that it reflects the theme of competition and admiration among women, specifically in the case of the womens reaction to Josephs beauty. The womens reaction to Joseph can be seen as a form of admiration or attraction towards a male figure, which in the context of the Electra complex, can symbolize the daughters desire to compete with her mother for the fathers attention or affection. Just as the women in the verse express admiration for Joseph, a similar dynamic can be perceived in the concept of Electra complex where a girl may experience feelings of competition and jealousy towards her mother for the fathers love and attention.

Description: This proposes a lifespan model of development, comprising eight stages from infancy to late adulthood. Every stage presents a crisis deriving from a conflict between personal impulse and the social world, resolution of which leads to competence in a specific area of life.
Translation: O you who have believed, fear Allah as He should be feared and do not die except as Muslims [in submission to Him].
Relation: This verse highlights the idea of being conscious of ones actions and decisions throughout life, which is a key aspect of Eriksons stages of psychosocial development. Just like in Eriksons theory where individuals face various crises at different stages of life that shape their development, the concept of fearing Allah and being in submission to Him emphasizes the importance of navigating lifes challenges with a sense of moral duty and integrity. By aligning ones actions with the fear of God and living a life of submission, individuals can seek resolution to the conflicts they encounter and strive towards competence and fulfillment in different areas of their life as per Erikson’s model.

Description: A term representing one pole of a personality dimension, extraversion is characterized by sociability, assertiveness, and a preference for company. Extraverts are energized by social interaction.
Translation: Recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book and establish prayer. Indeed, prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing, and the remembrance of Allah is greater. And Allah knows that which you do.
Relation: This verse encourages social interaction through the act of prayer, which is an essential aspect of Islam. Just as extraverts are energized by social interaction, believers in Islam are encouraged to engage in communal prayers and gatherings, fostering sociability and a sense of togetherness. Additionally, the concept of establishing prayer and remembering Allah can provide a sense of assertiveness and confidence in ones beliefs, reinforcing the characteristics associated with extraversion.

Description: A method employed during psychoanalysis, it involves the patient speaking freely about memories, dreams, or thoughts. It’s a tool that helps uncover repressed feelings and experiences.
Translation: And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. And He knows what is on the land and in the sea. Not a leaf falls but that He knows it. And no grain is there within the darknesses of the earth and no moist or dry [thing] but that it is [written] in a clear record.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Anam highlights the concept of free association in the context of the vast knowledge of Allah. In the process of free association during psychoanalysis, the patient is encouraged to speak openly and without censorship about their thoughts and feelings. Similarly, in this verse, it is emphasized that Allah knows every detail, even the unseen, the hidden aspects, and the smallest details. Just as free association allows hidden emotions and memories to come to light, the belief in Allahs all-encompassing knowledge encourages individuals to be honest and open in expressing their innermost thoughts and experiences.

Description: This is an unintentional error — verbal or memory — which unveils repressed feelings or thoughts. According to Freudian theory, these slips hint at the workings of the subconscious mind.
Translation: Do you not see that Allah knows whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth? There is no secret counsel of three but He is their fourth, nor of five but He is their sixth, nor fewer nor more, but He is with them wherever they may be; and thereafter, on the Day of Resurrection, He will inform them of what they did. Surely, Allah knows all things full well.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of nothing being hidden from Allah, as He is aware of all that is concealed in the hearts and minds of people. In the context of Freudian slip, where unintentional errors reveal repressed thoughts or feelings, this verse signifies that even our subconscious mind, with its hidden desires or emotions, is known to Allah. The Freudian slip can be seen as a manifestation of the subconscious coming to the surface, and this verse reflects the idea that nothing can truly be hidden from the divine knowledge.

Description: These are the three agents comprising the psychic apparatus defined by Freud. The Id is driven by primitive desires, the ego moderates between desires and reality, and the superego acts as the moral compass.
Translation: And if an evil suggestion comes to you from Satan, then seek refuge in Allah. Indeed, He is Hearing and Knowing.
Relation: This verse from the Quran can be related to the concept of Id, ego, and superego in psychoanalytic psychology. In Freudian terms, the evil suggestion that comes from Satan can be likened to the primitive desires of the Id that are driven by impulsive and instinctual urges. Seeking refuge in Allah can be seen as the moderating function of the ego, which helps in managing and balancing these desires with reality. The concept of Allahs guidance and protection can be associated with the superego, acting as the moral compass or conscience that guides individuals towards making ethical choices in line with divine teachings. Just as seeking refuge in Allah helps in resisting sinful urges and aligning with righteous behavior, the egos role in managing conflicts between desires and reality resonates with the guidance provided in this verse.

Description: The opposing trait to extraversion in personality psychology, introversion involves drawing energy from one’s internal world of thoughts, feelings, and ideas. Introverts tend to prefer solitude, intimate interactions over large gatherings, and often engage in introspective activities.
Translation: Indeed, hearts find rest in the remembrance of Allah.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Anam highlights the concept of introversion in a way that relates to finding solace, peace, and energy from ones internal world and introspective activities. Introverts often find comfort and tranquility in quiet contemplation, reflection, and connecting with their inner thoughts and emotions. The act of remembering Allah, which involves deep reflection, can provide a sense of calm and fulfillment to introverted individuals who draw energy from their internal world. It signifies the importance of seeking inner peace and solace through introspection and spiritual reflection, which aligns with the characteristics of introversion.

Description: In psychoanalytic theory, this term defines the sexual energy or force. Apart from strict sexual desire, this also extends to creative or productive drives in general.
Translation: And of His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought.
Relation: This verse from Surah Ar-Rum highlights the concept of libido from a broader perspective of companionship and emotional connections. In psychoanalytic terms, libido is not only about sexual energy but also about the drive for emotional fulfillment and meaningful relationships. The verse reflects how Allah has created the natural inclination for affection and companionship between individuals, encompassing the idea of libido as the force driving not only sexual desires but also the need for emotional bonding and tranquility in relationships. The mention of affection and mercy between mates in the verse emphasizes the broader aspect of libido, which includes the fulfillment of emotional and psychological needs through meaningful connections with others.

Description: This refers to interpersonal relations, emphasizing the internalization of experiences with significant others, particularly primary caretakers during early life. The term originates from psychoanalytic theory where “object” refers to the target of one’s drives and “relations” refers to interpersonal relationships.
Translation: And they say, Praise to God, who has favored us over many of His believing servants.
Relation: This verse relates to the concept of object relations in the sense of gratitude towards significant others. In the context of psychoanalytic theory, individuals internalize experiences with significant others, such as caretakers, which shapes their interpersonal relationships. In this verse, believers express their gratitude towards Allah for favoring them over others, highlighting the emotional connection, appreciation, and positive regard toward the object of their faith. This reflects the importance of internalizing positive object relations, such as feelings of gratitude and favor, which can greatly impact ones psychological well-being.

Description: This is a term from psychoanalytic theory, stating a child’s feelings of desire towards their opposite-sex parent and rivalry with their same-sex parent. Coined by Sigmund Freud, it’s considered a crucial stage in the formation of an individual’s sexual and social identities.
Translation: There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. The right course has become clear from the wrong. So whoever disbelieves in false deities and believes in Allah has grasped the most trustworthy handhold with no break in it. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
Relation: While this verse does not directly address the Oedipus complex, it highlights the concept of desire and belief. The natural feelings of desire and attachment that individuals may have towards their parents are a part of the fitrah (natural disposition) that Allah has created in humans. The verse emphasizes free will and choice in matters of faith and belief, which can be related to the psychological complexities of familial relationships and desires explored in the Oedipus complex within the context of human nature and decision-making.

Description: This Freudian concept is the governing force of the id, striving for immediate satisfaction of all wants, needs, and urges. Essentially, the urge to reduce tension by fulfilling desires characterizes human nature according to the pleasure principle.
Translation: And We have certainly created many of the jinn and mankind for Hell. They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. Those are like livestock; rather, they are more astray. It is they who are the heedless.
Relation: This verse from the Quran highlights the aspect of human nature that is governed by desires and immediate gratification, which is akin to the pleasure principle in psychoanalytic psychology. The reference to people being like livestock, devoid of deeper understanding, can be seen as an illustration of individuals who are solely driven by the pursuit of fulfilling their wants and desires without consideration of long-term consequences or higher purposes. Just as the pleasure principle emphasizes the seeking of pleasure and avoiding pain without rational thought, this verse underscores the heedlessness and lack of higher reasoning that can result from being solely driven by immediate satisfaction.

Description: As a psychological defense mechanism, projection involves attributing thoughts, feelings, or motives that are unacceptable or unwanted in oneself to someone else. Essentially, the individual “projects” undesired aspects onto others as a means of avoidance.
Translation: Allah does not burden a soul beyond that it can bear ...
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah emphasizes the concept of personal responsibility and accountability. In the context of projection as a defense mechanism, individuals often project their own burdens and negative aspects onto others in order to avoid facing them within themselves. However, this verse reminds believers that everyone is responsible for their own thoughts, feelings, and actions, and they should not burden themselves or others unjustly by projecting their own issues onto them. It encourages self-reflection, self-awareness, and taking ownership of ones emotions and behaviors rather than projecting them onto others.

Description: This concept, contrasting with the pleasure principle, is managed by the ego and seeks to satisfy the id’s desires realistically and in a socially appropriate manner. It nudges an understanding of the real world and adjusts actions accordingly.
Translation: And take provisions, but indeed, the best provision is Taqwa (piety, righteousness). So fear Me, O you of understanding.
Relation: This verse advises believers to take provisions before embarking on a journey, emphasizing the importance of realistic planning and preparation. By instilling Taqwa (piety and righteousness) as the ultimate provision, it highlights the concept of the reality principle in managing desires realistically and in a socially appropriate manner. Just as the verse encourages believers to act sensibly and make practical preparations for their journey, the reality principle, guided by the ego, helps individuals navigate the real world by adjusting their actions in accordance with social norms and realistic considerations.

Description: This defense mechanism involves burying distressful or unpleasant memories deep into the subconscious mind. It provides an escape from pain but can trigger anxiety, guilt, etc., indirectly influencing feelings and behaviors.
Translation: Then do you believe in a part of the Scripture and reject the rest? But what is the recompense for those who do that among you except disgrace in worldly life; and on the Day of Resurrection, they will be sent back to the severest punishment. And Allah is not unaware of what you do.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah addresses the concept of repression in a broader sense. When individuals engage in repressing distressful or unpleasant memories by selectively believing in only a part of the truth and denying or burying the rest deep into their subconscious mind, it can lead to negative consequences. Just as ignoring parts of the scripture can lead to disgrace in worldly life and severe punishment in the Hereafter, repressing unpleasant memories can lead to anxiety, guilt, and internal conflict. The verse highlights the importance of facing reality in its entirety rather than selectively repressing parts of it to avoid discomfort.

Description: In Jung’s psychoanalytic theory, the shadow represents the unconscious part of the personality that the conscious ego rejects or ignores. It’s often the source of negative human traits, but also consists of creativity and insight.
Translation: And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], Am I not your Lord? They said, Yes, we have testified. [This] - lest you should say on the day of Resurrection, Indeed, we were of this unaware.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of the unconscious part of human nature, similar to the Jungian concept of the shadow. In this verse, it is portrayed that humans have an inherent awareness of their connection to a higher power (Allah), but this awareness can become buried in the unconscious mind due to the distractions of the material world. It emphasizes the idea that there are deeper layers of the self that may be overlooked or rejected by the conscious ego, which aligns with the notion of the shadow in psychoanalytic psychology. The shadow aspect, like the unconscious connection to Allah in this verse, can hold both negative traits and hidden potentials waiting to be recognized and integrated into ones conscious awareness for personal growth and wholeness.

Description: This defense mechanism involves transforming unacceptable impulses or energies into socially acceptable actions or behaviors. It’s considered a mature way of dealing with inner conflict as the result is typically positive or beneficial.
Verse: Whatever good happens to you is from Allah, and whatever bad befalls you is from yourself. (4:79)
Translation: Whatever good comes to you, it is from Allah; and whatever bad befalls you, it is from yourself. And We have sent you [Muhammad] to the people as a messenger, and sufficient is Allah as Witness.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of taking responsibility for ones actions and outcomes, which is a key aspect of sublimation. In the process of sublimation, individuals acknowledge their inner conflicts and impulses, and instead of acting upon them in socially unacceptable ways, they channel these energies into positive and constructive behaviors. By recognizing that good and bad outcomes are linked to ones own actions, individuals can engage in self-reflection, accept responsibility, and strive towards transformation and personal growth. This verse emphasizes the importance of directing ones energies towards good deeds and taking ownership of ones choices, which is in line with the mature coping mechanism of sublimation in psychoanalytic psychology.

Description: This Jungian concept refers to meaningful coincidences that seemingly lack a causal connection. Jung proposed synchronicity could be an explanation for parapsychological phenomena.
Translation: To Allah belongs the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth. And the command for the Hour is but as a glance of the eye or it is nearer. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
Relation: This verse emphasizes the belief in the unseen aspects of the world that are beyond our understanding and perception. Synchronicity, as a concept of meaningful coincidences without a clear causal connection, can be seen as part of the unseen or divine aspects of the universe that are beyond our comprehension. It highlights the idea that there are forces at work in the world that may be beyond our immediate awareness or explanation, similar to how synchronicity involves events that seem connected in a meaningful way despite lacking an obvious cause and effect relationship.

Description: In psychoanalytic therapy, this features the redirection of feelings for a significant person to the therapist. It’s an unconscious process where the client projects feelings coming from past experiences onto the therapist.
Translation: And certainly you have come to Us individually as We created you the first time, and you have left behind that which We bestowed upon you. And We do not see with you your ’intercessors‘ about whom you asserted that they were Allah’s partners in respect to you. Certainly (all) the ties between you have been cut off, and that which you used to assert has failed you.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of transference in a broader sense by emphasizing the individuals direct relationship and return to Allah without any intermediaries. In psychoanalytic terms, transference involves projecting feelings onto another person, often due to unresolved issues from the past. However, this verse reminds us that ultimately, our connection with Allah is direct and devoid of any projections or intermediaries. It underscores the importance of addressing and resolving our feelings and issues directly with Allah without the need for transferring them onto others.

Description: This is a behavioral treatment technique, used mainly to cease harmful habits and behaviors. It employs negative stimuli paired with the behavior to create a revulsion and thus condition the individual to avoid it.
Translation: Fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you. But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you; and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah knows, while you know not.
Relation: In this verse, Allah acknowledges that there may be things that are disliked or aversive to individuals, yet these things may ultimately be beneficial. Aversion therapy works on a similar principle by employing negative stimuli to create discomfort or aversion towards certain behaviors, with the intention of promoting positive change. Just as individuals may dislike the process of aversion therapy initially but benefit from it in the long run, the verse highlights the idea that what is perceived as aversive may actually hold benefits beyond ones immediate understanding.

Description: This denotes a sequence of responses where each act serves both as a condition for the next and a result of the previous one. It’s a structure where one behavior leads to another, creating a ‘chain’ of actions.
Translation: Allah does not burden a soul beyond that it can bear...
Relation: This verse highlights the concept in which the Quran assures believers that they are not burdened with more than they can handle. In the context of a behavior chain, this verse implies that in any given sequence of actions or behaviors, an individual is capable of managing and handling each step as they come. The idea is that each behavior in the chain is manageable and within ones capacity to handle, just like how Allah does not burden a soul beyond its capability. This reassurance can help individuals navigate behavior chains with a sense of empowerment and capability, knowing that they have the strength to deal with each step in the sequence.

Description: Broadly, it’s a therapeutic approach that aims to change maladaptive behaviors through altering environmental factors, reinforcers, and consequences. It employs techniques derived from operant and classical conditioning and has its roots in behaviorism.
Translation: Indeed, Allah orders justice and good conduct and giving to relatives and forbids immorality and bad conduct and oppression. He admonishes you that perhaps you will be reminded.
Relation: This verse from Surah An-Nahl highlights the importance of behavior modification in the context of Islamic teachings. Here, Allah emphasizes the promotion of good conduct and righteousness while prohibiting immorality and oppression. This instruction aligns with the concept of behavior modification, as it involves changing maladaptive behaviors by reinforcing positive actions and discouraging negative ones. By following Allahs guidance to engage in just and virtuous behavior, Muslims are encouraged to modify their conduct in a way that leads to personal growth and spiritual development.

Description: A process envisaged by Ivan Pavlov, it involves forming an association between two stimuli. The former neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus evoking a conditioned response after repeated pairing with an unconditioned stimulus that naturally elicits an unconditioned response.
Translation: Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of classical conditioning in a spiritual and psychological context. Classical conditioning involves the formation of associations between stimuli, and in this verse, Allah emphasizes that changes in behavior and conditions are linked to internal changes within individuals. Just as in classical conditioning, where an association is formed between stimuli, here the verse suggests that changes in ones external environment are contingent upon inner changes within oneself. It signifies the importance of personal growth and transformation in influencing ones circumstances and behavior.

Description: This is a reinforcement schedule where each occurrence of a specific behavior is reinforced. It’s the simplest schedule where reinforcement occurs every time the desired behavior happens.
Translation: The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] which grows seven spikes; in each spike is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah speaks about the concept of continuous reinforcement in a spiritual context. Just as in continuous reinforcement where each instance of a behavior is rewarded, here the act of spending wealth in the way of Allah is likened to planting a seed that grows into a bountiful harvest. The continuous act of charity is continuously rewarded by Allah, emphasizing the idea of consistent reinforcement for a specific behavior. This can serve as a reminder of the positive outcomes that can result from consistent and continuous acts of goodness and generosity in the eyes of Allah.

Description: A therapeutic technique used to replace unwanted responses to stimuli with desired ones. It occurs when an individual associates something feared or avoided with positive outcomes, effectively undoing the condition.
Translation: Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and argue with them in a way that is best. Indeed, your Lord is most knowing of who has strayed from His way, and He is most knowing of who is [rightly] guided.
Relation: This verse from Surah An-Nahl emphasizes the importance of using wisdom and good instruction when guiding or counseling others. In the context of counterconditioning, we can see a parallel with the concept of replacing unwanted responses with desired ones. By inviting others towards positive behaviors and beliefs in a gentle and wise manner, one can help them overcome negative associations and fears. Through positive reinforcement and guidance, individuals can gradually replace their unwanted responses with more desired and beneficial ones, similar to the process of counterconditioning in behavioral psychology.

Description: In conditioning, this refers to the progressive decrease and disappearance of a conditioned response. Occurs when the association between the conditioned stimulus and conditioned response weakens due to absence of reinforcement.
Translation: Allah does not burden a soul beyond that it can bear...
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah highlights the concept of resilience and the ability to endure challenges. In the context of extinction in behavioral psychology, just as individuals can adapt and overcome various trials without being overwhelmed, the conditioned response may gradually decrease and disappear when the reinforcement is removed. It signifies that Allah has created humans with the capacity to withstand difficulties and adapt to changing circumstances, similar to how conditioned responses weaken in the absence of reinforcement.

Description: This reinforcement schedule delivers reinforcement after a certain, fixed interval of time following the desired response. Here, the behavior increases as the time for potential reinforcement nears.
Translation: And those who do not invoke with Allah another deity or kill the soul which Allah has forbidden [to be killed], except by right, and do not commit unlawful sexual intercourse. And whoever should do that will meet a penalty.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of fixed-interval schedule reinforcement in a moral context. In the behavioral psychology framework, reinforcement is provided after a specific, fixed interval of time following a desired action. Similarly, in this verse from the Quran, it is emphasized that wrongdoing and sin will result in a penalty or consequence, which may occur after a certain fixed interval of time. The fear of consequences following prohibited actions can serve as a form of reinforcement to discourage individuals from engaging in negative behaviors. Just as the concept of fixed-interval schedule reinforcement influences behavior in psychology, the anticipation of consequences in the afterlife, as mentioned in this verse, can influence moral behavior in individuals.

Description: This is designed to reinforce behavior after a fixed number of responses. Responding occurs at a high rate provided the number of behaviors required is not excessively high.
Translation: Is the reward for good [anything] but good?
Relation: This verse can be related to the psychological concept of fixed-ratio schedule in the context of reinforcement. In behavioral psychology, a fixed-ratio schedule involves providing reinforcement after a fixed number of responses. Similarly, the concept of reciprocity and reward for good deeds is emphasized in this verse from Surah Al-Rahman. The verse highlights the principle that good deeds are rewarded with goodness, thereby reinforcing the behavior of doing good as a fixed-ratio schedule reinforces desired behavior after a certain number of responses. Just as in the concept of fixed-ratio schedule, where behaviors are encouraged through regular reinforcement, the Quranic verse emphasizes the positive reinforcement of good deeds with goodness.

Description: This instinctive learning process involves decreased response to a recurring stimulus. Essentially, organisms become ‘used to’ stimuli through repeated exposure and respond less.
Translation: And this worldly life is not but diversion and amusement. And indeed, the home of the Hereafter - that is the [eternal] life, if only they knew.
Relation: This verse reminds believers that the distractions and pleasures of this world are transient and temporary, akin to habituation where responses decrease with repeated exposure. Just as habituation involves getting used to stimuli through repeated exposure, the verse emphasizes the idea that the allure of worldly pleasures should not distract one from the eternal life and ultimate purpose in the Hereafter. It serves as a reminder to not become desensitized or overly attached to the fleeting distractions of the material world, but to focus on the everlasting life that awaits in the Hereafter.

Description: Motivating operations are environmental variables that alter the effectiveness of a reinforcer and the frequency of behaviors that have previously been reinforced by that stimulus.
Translation: And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good. (Quran 29:69)
Relation: This verse from the Quran highlights the concept of motivating operations and reinforcement in behavioral psychology. In this verse, Allah promises guidance to those who strive and do good deeds. Here, the act of striving or putting effort towards righteousness is depicted as a motivating operation that enhances the effectiveness of the reinforcement, which is Allahs guidance. The verse suggests that by engaging in behaviors that are pleasing to Allah, individuals can increase the likelihood of receiving guidance and blessings from Him. Just like how motivating operations alter the effectiveness of reinforcers in behavior, the act of striving in the path of Allah can amplify the rewards and guidance one receives.

Description: A type of operant conditioning, it involves subtraction of something desirable to curtail undesired behavior. For example, taking away a favorite toy when a child misbehaves.
Translation: But when trouble toucheth man, he crieth unto Us: When We bestow a favor upon him as from Us, he saith, This is due to me: but when we test him, he says, My Lord has humiliated me! (Pickthall)
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of negative punishment in a spiritual and psychological context. When a person experiences a setback or faces difficulties (negative punishment), they may turn to God and recognize their mistakes. In the verse, it is depicted that when a favor is taken away (something desirable is subtracted), such as in times of trial and tribulation, some people may realize their faults and seek guidance from God. Hence, the removal of a favor serves as a form of negative punishment to correct behaviors and bring about humility and reflection in individuals.

Description: This aspect of operant conditioning strengthens a behavior through removal of a negative condition. For instance, taking painkillers (behavior) to alleviate pain (negative condition).
Translation: For indeed, with hardship [will be] ease. Indeed, with hardship [will be] ease.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Inshirah highlights the concept of negative reinforcement in the context of psychological resilience. Just as the removal of a negative condition (hardship) leads to ease, negative reinforcement in operant conditioning involves strengthening a behavior by removing a negative condition. When faced with challenges or hardships in life, it is important to remember that relief and ease will follow, similar to how negative reinforcement can lead to the strengthening of a behavior through the removal of an aversive stimulus. This verse serves as a reminder of the cyclical nature of negative conditions and subsequent positive outcomes, providing hope and encouragement during difficult times.

Description: Albert Bandura theorized this process where individuals learn by observing others’ behavior. Modeling involves imitation, where behaviors are copied based on the perceived consequences to the model.
Translation: And if We had willed, We could have elevated him thereby, but he adhered [instead] to the earth and followed his own desire. So his example is like that of the dog: if you chase him, he pants, or if you leave him, he [still] pants. That is the example of the people who denied Our signs. So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought.
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of observational learning in the context of negative behavior. It draws a parallel between individuals who choose to follow their own desires without seeking elevation or guidance, and the behavior of a dog that continues panting whether chased or left alone. The verse emphasizes the consequences of deviating from righteousness and the importance of reflecting on the stories and signs provided for guidance. In the context of modeling, it underscores the significance of choosing positive role models and behaviors to emulate rather than following base desires without purpose or benefit.

Description: This is a learning method which manipulates the consequences of behavior as an incentive for response. It’s divided into reinforcement (strengthening behavior) and punishment (weakening behavior).
Translation: Say, Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good [lawful] things of provision? Say, They are for those who believe during the worldly life [but] exclusively for them on the Day of Resurrection. Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know.
Relation: In this verse, Allah emphasizes the concept of reinforcement, strengthening behavior in the context of following lawful provisions and adornments that have been provided by Him. Just as in operant conditioning, where reinforcement is used to strengthen behavior, in the Quran, Allah encourages believers to adopt and adhere to good and lawful behaviors in this world as a form of reinforcement for their faith and obedience. The promised reward on the Day of Resurrection serves as the ultimate reinforcement for believers who choose to follow the righteous path.

Description: Here, only some responses are reinforced, making the behavior more resistant to extinction. This can occur on a variety of schedules, including the fixed and variable schedules based on ratio or interval.
Translation: And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, seeking His countenance. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring adornments of the worldly life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is ever [in] neglect.
Relation: This verse highlights the importance of patience and perseverance in seeking the pleasure of Allah. In the concept of partial reinforcement, where only some responses are rewarded, it is essential to maintain patience and consistency in ones actions and beliefs. Just like how in intermittent reinforcement, not every response is reinforced, believers are urged to remain steadfast in their faith and worship, regardless of the immediate outcomes or rewards, with the assurance that their efforts will be recognized and rewarded by Allah in the future.

Description: This aspect of operant conditioning weakens the probability of a behavior by adding an undesirable consequence. For example, an individual receives a parking fine (addition of negative element) for parking illegally (behavior).
Verse: Wherever you may be, death will overtake you, even if you should be within towers of lofty construction.
Translation: Wherever you are, death will overtake you, even if you should be within towers of lofty construction. (Quran 4:78)
Relation: This verse emphasizes the inevitability of consequences, even in seemingly secure or fortified situations. In the context of positive punishment, where an undesired consequence is added to decrease a behaviors likelihood, the verse serves as a reminder that no one can escape the consequences of their actions. Just like how the undesirable consequence of death will eventually reach everyone, the application of positive punishment aims to deter or weaken certain behaviors by associating them with negative outcomes, leading to a modification in behavior.

Description: This principle of operant conditioning strengthens a behavior by providing a positive stimulus or reward as a consequence. For instance, praise can reinforce the act of completing homework on time.
Translation: This is indeed the supreme success.
Relation: This verse emphasizes the concept of positive reinforcement by highlighting the ultimate reward and success that comes from following the guidance of Allah. In behavioral psychology, positive reinforcement involves providing a reward or positive stimulus to strengthen a desired behavior. Just as the promise of success in the hereafter serves as a reinforcement for righteous actions in Islam, positive reinforcement in behavioral psychology acts as a motivator for individuals to continue engaging in behaviors that lead to positive outcomes. The verse encourages believers to strive for success through obedience and righteousness, drawing a parallel to the psychological principle of positive reinforcement in reinforcing desired behaviors through the promise of reward.

Description: An idea from behaviorism, it dictates a more preferred activity can reinforce a less preferred one. Known as “grandma’s rule” — first, you work, then you play — it encourages good behavior with the promise of a desired reward.
Translation: Indeed, We guided him to the way, whether he be grateful or ungrateful.
Relation: This verse emphasizes the idea that guidance is provided, whether one chooses to be grateful or ungrateful. In the context of the Premack principle, the reinforcement of being guided towards the right path is always available, regardless of ones initial preference or attitude. Just as the more preferred activity can reinforce a less preferred one in the Premack principle, the offer of guidance and reward is constant and accessible, irrespective of ones initial inclination. The concept of offering a reward for choosing the right path aligns with the notion of reinforcing good behavior with the promise of a desired outcome, as highlighted in the Premack principle.

Description: A conditioning paradigm, it gradually teaches new behaviors through reinforcement of successive approximations towards the desired outcome. Thus, it shapes behavior, bringing it closer to the desired final act.
Translation: Never will you attain the good [reward] until you spend [in the way of Allah] from that which you love. And whatever you spend - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Imran highlights the concept of shaping behavior through reinforcement, as seen in the context of charitable giving. In the concept of shaping, new behaviors are gradually taught through reinforcing successive approximations towards the desired outcome. Similarly, in this verse, believers are encouraged to give from what they love, implying that by engaging in acts of charity and sacrifice, ones behavior is shaped towards embodying the qualities of generosity, selflessness, and obedience to Allah. The verse emphasizes that true spiritual growth and reward are achieved when individuals consistently practice and shape their behavior by giving from what they hold dear, reinforcing the development of virtuous traits.

Description: A differentiation process in learning and conditioning, it enables an individual to distinguish between similar stimuli. The organism learns to respond differently as only one of the stimuli is consistent with the conditioned response.
Translation: Guide us to the Straight Way
Relation: In this verse, Muslims seek guidance from Allah to show them the correct path or way. This can be related to the concept of stimulus discrimination in behavioral psychology. Through the process of learning and conditioning, individuals are taught to differentiate between various stimuli, just like how Muslims are asking for guidance to discern the right path from potential misleading paths. By seeking guidance from Allah, individuals can develop the ability to distinguish between right and wrong, similar to how stimulus discrimination helps individuals respond differently based on specific stimuli.

Description: Contrary to stimulus discrimination, it describes a situation where similar stimuli elicit the same response. For instance, a child conditioned to fear a specific dog may start fearing all dogs.
Translation: The weakened you feared the strong. But today I shall cast fear into the hearts of the strongest of them, while the people of reason have no fear.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Araf highlights the concept of stimulus generalization in the context of fear. It depicts a psychological response where the fear of a specific situation or entity (in this case, the strong) generalizes to encompass a wider range of stimuli. The verse indicates that even those who were initially strong and feared by others may begin to experience fear themselves, demonstrating how fear can generalize across different stimuli and contexts.

Description: A behavioral therapy technique designed to reduce phobias and other abnormal fears. It entails a gradual process where individuals face the feared object or situation in a safe and controlled way until anxiety declines.
Translation: And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war by which you may terrify the enemy of Allah and your enemy and others besides them whom you do not know but whom Allah knows. And whatever you spend in the cause of Allah will be fully repaid to you, and you will not be wronged.
Relation: This verse highlights the aspect of facing fears and challenges with preparation and power. In systematic desensitization, individuals gradually face their fears in a controlled manner to reduce anxiety and overcome phobias. Just as the verse encourages believers to prepare against their enemies with strength and without fear, systematic desensitization encourages individuals to confront their fears in a systematic and gradual way to diminish their impact. Both emphasize the importance of facing fears and challenges to overcome them successfully.

Description: A positive reinforcement strategy in behaviour therapy, using tokens as rewards for appropriate behavior. Collected tokens can, thereafter, be exchanged for desired rewards or privileges.
Translation: The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] which grows seven spikes; in every spike is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
Relation: This verse demonstrates the concept of rewarding positive behavior and acts of charity. In a token economy system, individuals are rewarded with tokens for demonstrating desired behaviors. Similarly, in the Islamic concept of charity, believers are rewarded abundantly by Allah for spending their wealth in His way. The idea of reward multiplication in this verse is akin to the principle of accumulating tokens for later exchange for desired rewards or privileges in a token economy system. Just as the verse highlights the abundant rewards for charitable acts, the token economy reinforces positive behaviors by providing tokens that can be exchanged for rewards, thereby encouraging and maintaining the desired behavior.

Description: This reinforcement schedule provides reinforcement for the first response after an inconsistent period. It causes a steady, moderate rate of response, with the individual unaware of the exact timing of reinforcement.
Translation: The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] which grows seven spikes; in each spike is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
Relation: This verse illustrates the concept of variable-interval schedule in a spiritual context. Just as in the concept where reinforcement is provided at unpredictable intervals to maintain a moderate rate of response, Allahs reward for those who spend their wealth in His way is depicted as growing and multiplying in ways unknown to humans. The believers continue to strive and perform acts of charity without knowing the exact timing or quantity of the rewards, akin to the individual unaware of the exact timing of reinforcement in a variable-interval schedule. The verse emphasizes the faith, patience, and consistency required in pursuing good deeds without immediate, predictable returns.

Description: This schedule reinforces behavior after a fluctuating number of responses. Typically, it leads to a high and stable rate of responding with the reinforcement always remaining uncertain.
Translation: And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Ankabut highlights the concept of variable-ratio schedule in the context of striving and effort. In a variable-ratio schedule, reinforcement is provided after an unpredictable number of responses. Similarly, in the pursuit of striving for the path of Allah, believers are not explicitly told when or how their efforts will be rewarded, creating uncertainty similar to the variable nature of reinforcement in this psychological concept. The promise of guidance and support from Allah for those who strive reinforces their behavior of good deeds, maintaining a high and stable rate of engaging in righteous actions despite the uncertainty of the exact timing or form of the reward.

Description: This is a cognitive adaptation process wherein existing frameworks of understanding are adjusted to incorporate new information. It’s a part of Jean Piaget’s paradigm of cognitive development.
Translation: He grants wisdom to whom He pleases, and whoever is granted wisdom, he indeed is given a great good and none but men of understanding remember. (2:269)
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah speaks about the granting of wisdom by Allah to whom He pleases. In the context of cognitive psychology and the concept of accommodation, wisdom can be seen as the ability to adapt and adjust ones existing frameworks of understanding to incorporate new information. It implies that those who are granted wisdom are open-minded and receptive to new knowledge, which aligns with the idea of accommodating new information into ones cognitive schema. The concept of accommodation, as defined by Jean Piaget, involves adjusting ones existing cognitive structures to incorporate new experiences or information, ultimately leading to cognitive growth and development. This verse emphasizes the importance of being open to acquiring wisdom and understanding, which involves the process of cognitive adaptation and accommodation.

Description: This refers to a cognitive bias where initial pieces of information are used as the reference point for future judgments. Individuals adjust their assessments from this initial ‘anchor,’ often insufficiently, hence being misled.
Translation: O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin. And do not spy or backbite each other. Would one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead? You would detest it. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is Accepting of repentance and Merciful.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Hujurat highlights the concept of anchoring and adjustment in the context of making assumptions about others. The verse warns against forming negative assumptions about people based on limited information or initial impressions. In cognitive psychology, anchoring and adjustment bias can lead individuals to rely heavily on their initial perceptions or judgments about someone and fail to adjust them adequately. Similarly, in this verse, Muslims are advised to avoid making excessive negative assumptions about others and instead practice fairness and mindfulness in their judgments. By not anchoring their beliefs on incomplete or biased information, individuals can prevent misunderstandings and misjudgments, fostering harmonious social interactions based on sound assessments rather than presumptions.

Description: In Piaget’s cognitive development theory, this is the process of integrating new information into existing cognitive schemas. It’s basic to learning and incorporates the novel experience within the prevailing understanding without changing the structure.
Translation: The Messenger has believed in what was revealed to him from his Lord, and [so have] the believers. All of them have believed in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers, [saying], We make no distinction between any of His messengers. And they say, We hear and we obey. [We seek] Your forgiveness, our Lord, and to You is the [final] destination.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah emphasizes the concept of assimilation in the cognitive sense as depicted in Piagets theory. The believers mentioned in the verse demonstrate their ability to integrate new information (revelations from Allah) into their existing cognitive schemas (their faith and beliefs) without altering the fundamental structure of their belief system. They accept and incorporate the new revelations from their Lord without making a distinction between different messengers or divine messages, demonstrating a seamless integration of new knowledge into their understanding of faith. This verse showcases how the believers cognitive schemas expand and adapt to new information while maintaining the coherence of their belief system, illustrating the skill of assimilation in a cognitive context as discussed in cognitive psychology.

Description: This theory asserts that attention is a resource distributed among tasks. Cognitive processes compete for these limited resources, hence it becomes difficult to adequately concentrate on multiple tasks simultaneously.
Translation: No! Indeed, man transgresses, because he sees himself self-sufficient.
Relation: This verse addresses the tendency of human beings to overextend their attentional resources, thinking they are self-sufficient and can handle numerous tasks simultaneously. It reflects the concept of limited attentional resources as mentioned in cognitive psychology, where trying to divide attention among multiple tasks can lead to transgressions or inefficiencies. The verse serves as a reminder to prioritize tasks and acknowledge the limitations of human attention and capacity.

Description: This is a classification of learning objectives within education proposed by Benjamin Bloom in 1956. It’s a framework for categorizing educational goals into six levels of complexity: Knowledge (Remember), Comprehension (Understand), Application (Apply), Analysis (Analyze), Synthesis (Evaluate), and Evaluation (Create). This hierarchy not only defines intellectual activities but also supports educators in creating more comprehensive lessons or tests.
Translation: He gives wisdom to whom He wills, and whoever has been given wisdom has certainly been given much good. And none will remember except those of understanding.
Relation: This verse emphasizes the importance of wisdom and understanding in the context of learning. In Blooms Taxonomy, the levels of comprehension and knowledge are crucial for effective learning. The verse reflects the idea that true wisdom and knowledge are granted by Allah to those who possess understanding. It highlights the value of comprehension and knowledge acquisition in achieving higher levels of cognitive functioning, which correlates with Blooms Taxonomys focus on progressing from basic levels of remembering and understanding to higher levels of analyzing, evaluating, and creating.

Description: Leon Festinger’s theory proposes discomfort arises when individuals face conflicting beliefs or actions. For resolution, they either change their beliefs, acquire new ones to create coherence, or trivialize the conflict.
Translation: And We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], the Book in truth, confirming that which preceded it of the Scripture and as a criterion over it. So judge between them by what Allah has revealed and do not follow their inclinations away from what has come to you of the truth.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Maida emphasizes the importance of seeking coherence and truth in beliefs and actions. It highlights the need to resolve conflicts by adhering to the truth revealed by Allah, even if it challenges ones existing beliefs or inclinations. In the context of cognitive dissonance, individuals facing conflicting beliefs or actions can find guidance in resolving their internal conflicts by seeking the ultimate truth and aligning themselves with it, just as the verse instructs to judge between conflicting beliefs based on what Allah has revealed. This encourages individuals to strive for internal harmony and consistency by prioritizing the truth over personal desires or conflicting beliefs, mirroring the resolution process proposed by the concept of cognitive dissonance.

Description: This term refers to the total mental effort being used in the working memory. It delineates the load related to a specific task, which can impede learning if it exceeds the individual’s cognitive capacity.
Translation: Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity. It will have [the consequence of] what [good] it has gained, and it will bear [the consequence of] what [evil] it has earned...
Relation: This verse highlights the concept of cognitive load by emphasizing the principle of not burdening a soul beyond its capacity. In cognitive psychology, cognitive load refers to the mental effort and capacity that individuals have for processing information and tasks in their working memory. The verse reminds believers that Allah does not burden them with more than they can bear, which can serve as a source of comfort and guidance when individuals feel overwhelmed by cognitive tasks or challenges. Just as Allah understands each individuals capacity, it is essential for individuals to be mindful of their cognitive load and not exceed their mental capacity, as exceeding cognitive load can impede learning and cognitive functioning. This verse serves as a reminder to manage ones cognitive load effectively to ensure optimal performance and well-being.

Description: This is an internal mental representation of spatially arranged elements in the world. Tolman’s theory suggests organisms have such maps which help in navigation and understanding of the environment.
Verse: 64:And this worldly life is not but diversion and amusement. And indeed, the home of the Hereafter - that is the [eternal] life, if only they knew.
Translation: The worldly life is just a temporary enjoyment, whereas the Hereafter is the true life if only they knew.
Relation: This verse highlights the temporary nature of worldly life and the importance of focusing on the eternal life of the Hereafter. In the context of cognitive maps, one could interpret this as a reminder to not get too attached to the material aspects of this world and instead have a cognitive map that prioritizes the eternal aspect of the Hereafter. Just as a cognitive map helps in navigating physical spaces, this verse serves as a reminder to maintain a clear mental representation of our ultimate destination and purpose beyond the physical world.

Description: A core part of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), it involves changing negative or irrational thoughts to reduce psychological discomfort. This approach helps individuals counteract cognitive distortions, often associated with mental health disorders.
Translation: Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves. And when Allah intends for a people ill, there is no repelling it. And there is not for them besides Him any patron.
Relation: This verse highlights the importance of internal change for external outcomes. Cognitive restructuring involves changing negative or irrational thoughts within oneself, which aligns with the idea that Allah does not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves. By engaging in cognitive restructuring, individuals can work towards improving their mental health and well-being, ultimately leading to positive changes in their lives.

Description: Based on the work of David Jonassen, this term refers to any device assisting with cognitive processes, such as memory, reasoning, and learning. Examples include mnemonics, mind maps, calculators, and digital technology like learning apps or cognitive training programs. These tools amplify cognitive abilities and compensates for cognitive deficits or weaknesses.
Translation: O you who have believed, when you contract a debt for a specified term, write it down. And let a scribe write [it] between you in justice. Let no scribe refuse to write as Allah has taught him. So let him write and let the one who has the obligation dictate. And let him fear Allah, his Lord, and not leave anything out of it. But if the one who has the obligation is of limited understanding or weak or unable to dictate himself, then let his guardian dictate in justice. And bring to witness two witnesses from among your men. And if there are not two men [available], then a man and two women from those whom you accept as witnesses – so that if one of the women errs, then the other can remind her.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Baqarah emphasizes the importance of documenting agreements and contracts to avoid any misunderstandings or disputes. The act of writing down debts and having witnesses serves as a cognitive tool to enhance memory, reasoning, and learning in financial transactions. Just as the Quran instructs believers to utilize writing and witnesses as cognitive tools to keep accurate records and prevent cognitive deficits in understanding or recalling obligations, modern cognitive tools such as mnemonics, mind maps, and digital technologies also aid individuals in organizing and processing information effectively. Using cognitive tools enhances cognitive abilities and compensates for weaknesses, similar to the guidance provided in this Quranic verse for ensuring clarity and accuracy in dealings.

Description: This pervasive cognitive bias leads individuals to favor information that confirms their existing beliefs or hypotheses. It often leads to statistical errors and poor decision-making.
Translation: And We have set none but angels as guardians of the Fire; and We have fixed their number only as a trial for the disbelievers, in order that the People of the Book may arrive at certainty, and the believers may increase in faith – and so that no doubts may be left for the People of the Book and the believers – and so that those in whose hearts is a disease and the disbelievers may say, What could Allah intend by this example? Thus Allah leads astray whom He wills and guides whom He wills. None knows the hosts of your Lord save Him. This is naught but a reminder for mankind.
Relation: This verse from the Quran highlights the concept of confirmation bias by emphasizing the importance of arriving at certainty and increasing faith through the messages and signs from Allah. The mention of how those with diseases in their hearts and disbelievers may question the intentions behind the examples given by Allah reflects the tendency of individuals to prefer information that aligns with their beliefs or doubts. Just as confirmation bias can lead to poor decision-making and errors in judgment, the verse reminds believers of the importance of being open-minded and seeking certainty in faith without falling prey to biased interpretations.

Description: Refers to the cognitive capacity to attend to multiple tasks at once. It’s a component of multitasking but can often result in decreased overall performance due to attentional resources being split.
Translation: And whatever payment you give - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it.
Relation: This verse reminds us of the importance of focusing our attention and intention when carrying out tasks. In the context of divided attention, it highlights the significance of being mindful and fully present in each task we undertake, as Allah is aware of our actions even when our attention is divided. By prioritizing our focus and intention, we can strive for better performance and spiritual fulfillment, aligning with the concept of divided attention in cognitive psychology.

Description: Paivio’s proposition suggests information is processed in two ways: verbal and visual. Therefore, learning can be enhanced by using both channels simultaneously to encode information.
Translation: And thus do We detail the verses, and [thus] the way of the criminals will become evident.
Relation: This verse speaks about how Allah presents His messages in different ways to ensure clarity and understanding for different types of people. In the context of the Dual-coding theory of cognitive psychology, where information is processed verbally and visually, this verse emphasizes the importance of presenting information in multiple channels to aid comprehension and memory retention. By using both verbal and visual channels, individuals can better encode and retain the message being conveyed, making it more accessible and evident.

Description: Also known as declarative memory, it pertains to conscious, intentional recollection of factual information, prior experiences, and concepts. It can further be divided into episodic (personal events) and semantic (general facts) memory.
Translation: O you who have believed, when you contract a debt for a specified term, write it down. And let a scribe write [it] between you in justice. Let no scribe refuse to write as Allah has taught him. So let him write and let the one who has the obligation dictate. And let him fear Allah, his Lord, and not leave anything out of it. But if the one who has the obligation is of limited understanding or weak or unable to dictate himself, then let his guardian dictate in justice. And bring to witness two witnesses from among your men. And if there are not two men [available], then a man and two women from those whom you accept as witnesses - so that if one of the women errs, then the other can remind her.
Relation: This verse from the Quran emphasizes the importance of documenting agreements and transactions for accountability and accuracy. In the context of explicit memory, the act of writing down debts or agreements serves as a tool to help in the recollection of factual information and past events. It highlights the significance of conscious and intentional recollection of information, as mentioned in the concept of explicit memory. By recording information, be it financial transactions or agreements, individuals are better able to retain and recall these details accurately, aligning with the principles of declarative memory.

Description: These are highly detailed and vivid ‘snapshot’ memories of momentous events. Often marked by strong emotional content, they feel as vivid as photographs, hence the name.
Translation: And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], Am I not your Lord? They said, Yes, we have testified. [This] lest you should say on the Day of Resurrection, Indeed, we were of this unaware.
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Araf can be related to the concept of Flashbulb Memory in cognitive psychology. Just as flashbulb memories are highly detailed and vivid recollections of momentous events, the concept of humans testifying their acknowledgment of the Lord in a significant moment in human history is also deeply ingrained in memory. The strong emotional content of this event, the sense of witness and the vividness with which it is described in the Quran resonates with the idea of flashbulb memories. This event is etched in the memory of all humans as a pivotal moment, much like how flashbulb memories capture key moments in ones personal history.

Description: A cognitive bias limiting a person to use objects only in the traditional way. This inhibition of viewing things from a novel perspective hampers problem-solving and creativity.
Translation: Say, Not equal are the evil and the good, although the abundance of evil might impress you. So fear Allah, O you of understanding, that you may be successful. (Quran 5:100)
Relation: This verse from Surah Al-Maidah highlights the concept of functional fixedness by addressing the bias that arises from being impressed solely by the abundance of evil deeds or traditional ways of thinking. Just as functional fixedness limits individuals to conventional ways of using objects, the verse cautions against being swayed by the prevalence of negative actions or rigid thought patterns. It encourages individuals to have understanding (critical thinking) and to not be entrapped by the traditional or common way of viewing things, urging them to fear Allah and seek success through exploring innovative solutions and perspectives beyond the ordinary.

Description: These are mental shortcuts or ‘rules of thumb’ used for quick decision making. While often helpful, heuristics can also lead to cognitive biases and systematic errors.
Translation: And when it is said to them, Follow what Allah has revealed, they say, Rather, we will follow that which we found our fathers doing. Even though their fathers understood nothing, nor were they guided?
Relation: This verse touches upon the concept of heuristics in cognitive psychology by highlighting how individuals may rely on inherited beliefs or traditions (mental shortcuts) without critically evaluating their validity. The verse cautions against blindly following traditions or societal norms without seeking understanding or guidance, as this can lead to cognitive biases and errors. It serves as a reminder for individuals to engage in critical thinking and reflection rather than relying solely on heuristics when making important decisions or judgments.

Description: This involves complex cognitive processes that go beyond basic information processing. Popularized by Bloom’s Taxonomy, this encompasses critical, logical, reflective, and creative thinking, requiring individuals to synthesize, analyze, reason, comprehend, and interpret information. Higher-order thinking is intricately linked with problem-solving, decision making, and the transfer of knowledge across contexts.
Translation: Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding. Who remember Allah while standing or sitting or [lying] on their sides and give thought to the creation of the heavens and the earth, [saying], Our Lord, You did not create this aimlessly; exalted are You [above such a thing]; then protect us from the punishment of the Fire.
Relation: This verse highlights the importance of reflecting upon the signs of creation and pondering over the intricate design and purpose behind them. It emphasizes the concept of higher-order thinking by encouraging individuals to engage in deep contemplation, logical reasoning, and critical analysis of the world around them. By connecting the creation of the heavens and the earth to the remembrance of Allah and seeking protection from punishment, the verse illustrates the cognitive processes involved in synthesizing information, analyzing complexities, and seeking deeper understanding beyond surface-level observations. It serves as a reminder for individuals to exercise their intellect and engage in reflective thinking to comprehend the wisdom and order in the universe.

Description: Unconscious memory or automatic memory, it’s demonstrated in tasks where previous experiences help perform a task without conscious awareness of these experiences. These may be procedural skills or conditioned responses.
